dict.string: Why do modern birds have the genes for teeth?
Why do blind cave fish still have functionless eyes if they live in darkness?
Why do we never find fossils in the wrong order, place, or time?
If mutations are so rare and extremely dangerous, why do we have 180-200 mutations that are completely distinct from our parents?

The word ‘mutation’ to many, means something terrible. But mutations are not only common, they are vital to evolution and our survival. When your parents developed their sperm and eggs they had small mutations occur that get passed on. Once conception happens, those mutations combine to equal around 180-200 new mutations in you alone! And this is the more conservative estimate.
These mutations more than likely have gone unnoticed; especially if you believe that a mutation causes gross abnormalities or disease every time. Mutations can absolutely cause genetic diseases, problems during fetal development, as well as switching on old genes for tails, but these are just the ones that are easily noticed! Most mutations will change only a small section of the DNA that don’t change anything in your body but will be given to your children regardless. Some mutations will cause a change that does something small and often not easily noticed like creating more ear wax or a stronger body odor.
Mutations cause there to be differences in every species. Hair color, eye color, lactose tolerance, voice depth, pelvis width, brain size and everything else you can think of can be changed. Mutations help us pass on immunities to deadly diseases like the black plague and malaria and can help us avoid extinction from starvation by allowing us to drink cow milk and eat wheat. If there are no mutations, and thus no variation in a population, there is no possibility to adapt when a crisis strikes. Thankfully this is not how our evolution works as we give 180-200 chances for our children to adapt. Those chances for change are called mutations.
Why did God create all these animals, only to allow 99.99% of them to die?

Around 99.99% of the species found in the fossil record are extinct, and we have 30-50 million species alive today. In summary, there have been A LOT of organisms on this planet. What happened to them?
Creationist opinions vary significantly: God created them and they all failed (why did 99.99% of his creations fail?), they died before the flood because they weren’t allowed on the ark (too big/too slow/something else made up), they made it on the ark but died/were killed after (specifically dinosaurs =not enough oxygen/too big and slow/eaten by man/starved)…
OR…evolution through natural selection (adaptation to environment and/or natural disasters, change in reproductive success, etc) caused the evolution and extinction of most life on earth. This one makes sense because not only is 4.5 billion years a VERY long time but most species either split and die off or develop into a new line. This line will then split and some branches will die and some will change and a few will stay the same (cockroaches). Anyone who knows simple multiplication knows that if you keep splitting 1 line into 2, after thousands of generations the amount of evolutionary lines is beyond anything we can imagine.
Most species only seem to survive .5-5 million years before splitting or going extinct. So with 4.5 billion years available to life on earth, 99.99% of all species being extinct might not be that surprising. But if the earth is only 6,000 – 10,000 years old, why is nearly all of God’s creation already been wiped out? And why would he have created them all, knowing they were all going to cease to exist so soon?
